job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Cleveland Heights, Cuyahoga, OH
pros: Staff was supportive...the students were there to make an effort. Very rewarding position.
cons: Schedules were erratic from term to term. Hard to make long term plans.

review_title: So much turnover at multiple campuses indicates a problem
pros: Pay is good and benefits are ok. I enjoy helping the students.
cons: There is so much turnover at multiple levels at multiple campuses that upper management needs to figure out what the common denominator is and fix the problem. For Academic Counselors they haven't been able to keep them in the position for 3 years because they haven't had their own supervisor. Everyone has known it's needed, but it hasn't been provided. You want to keep students but we're so overworked and understaffed, responsible for everything with new, continuing, and returning students. We can't do it all. We have multiple conflicting responsibilities and literal people at our doors every day demanding we do what they need RIGHT NOW. It's such a toxic and hostile environment. There is no consideration for our other responsibilities or why we can't process something right away.

pros: Beautiful building, supportive dean, nice coworkers
cons: For profit at the time

review_title: It was like the longest episode of Punk’d ever.
pros: Great job to get experience in higher education.
cons: No sick time . Must use you PTO which is prorated . If you resign it comes out of your paycheck . I’m 15 months I had 3 supervisors. Spent 5-6 months without a direct supervisor. High turnover in position. You may be the last man standing. Extremely heavy workload with unrealistic expectations. Inadequate training . Unethical admissions practices makes your job more difficult.

pros: The small building allowed for close parking and the small class/program sizes allowed for more meaningful interactions with students.
cons: Where to start?... -Leadership seemed far more concerned with power and control than with the actual well-being and learning of the students. -Students and staff had conveniences removed one after another in an effort to save a few pennies. -Neither administration nor human resources would effectively (if at all) manage employee issues, creating a culture of apathy toward adhering to procedures or honest work practices.

job_title: Director of Admissions in Savannah, GA
pros: I really enjoy the people I work with. The students are also wonderful.

pros: The students and coworkers are the best part of the job.
cons:
I have been at SU for 8 years, 7 as a FT Professor. Instructors and staff have not received received annual cost of living raises since I was hired. 

Faculty stay for the students, but NONE are satisfied with administration. Decisions are made out of Savannah, by leaders that are out of touch with faculty and staff that work directly with students. 

Support staff has decreased during my tenu, while individual job loads has significantly increased. Staff members are great, but they are spread to thin to give students the support they deserve.

pros: There are professors who genuinely care about the students and their education.
cons: Low pay, no merit increases in years, no 401k match, mediocre benefits. Incompetent management, out of touch with reality. Constant turnover. Run as fast as you can.

pros: small class sizes and small number of faculty
cons: constant layoffs, rigid rules, no focus on faculty development, seems not to care about most faculty, very cliquish, loves to bring back people who left, hires friends and family

pros: Great starting pay! In depth training and support systems in place

cons: Very political; lots of cronyism.

pros: none that would be positive

most unprofessional company i've ever seen
pay is an insult and they will lie to you repeatedly.
they also don't honor contracts so don't sign anything with them

pros: Talking to new people every day on the phone keeps things from growing stale.
cons: Deadlines can be difficult to meet.

review_title: High stress environment but overall enjoy what I do
job_title: Admissions Representative in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Good people to work with for the most part, good hours, and PTO, holidays off
cons: No raises in years, no 401 match, high stress, expected to more than what Is in your job description. No advancement opportunities

pros: This company is great, and ultimately treats its employees well. They are always throwing pizza parties, corn hole tournaments, and they are always trying to keep morale up -which is great!.... I loved this place for the first year I worked there, and then it turned to crap.
cons: They sneakily try to find ways to fire you if you are not a top performer. I was not a "top" performer... I was always somewhere in the middle, but the students I recruited loved me. I always went above and beyond with every student, and I got so many compliments from my students. Even my manager praised me quite often, and then all the sudden when I was 9 MONTHS PREGNANT they started using words like "struggling" to describe my work performance. They were honestly trying to fire me before my maternity leave. Such a disappointment. My manager used the phrase "I didn't know you already had your leave scheduled, that kind of threw a wrench into things..." when she tried to put me on a "corrective action" which basically would have given me 30 days to improve or I was let go. My maternity leave with literally in 20 something days from that moment, and I ended up going into labor early anyway. As soon as I told them I would not be there in 30 days to "reevaluate my performance" their whole tone changed..... such a shady experience. Needless to say I am looking for a new job while on maternity leave.

pros: money benefits pto work from home
cons: the leads, the quota, the management or lack of.

pros: No pros, they do not treat employees well
cons: If you don't meet quota, they will let you go based on performance.

pros: Convenient location in Chandler, Arizona. Close proximity to several shopping centers, eateries, and freeway access. Newer facility with good parking. Diverse employee base.
cons:
Operations and sales do not mix. Sales people should not be leading the operations folks and dictating how they go about their daily duties. There is no clear line of leadership among the departments within the University at the online location in Arizona. Senior Leadership from Pittsburgh visits occasionally, however their presence is merely for appearance purposes and nothing more. 
If you enjoy a high pressure, numbers based, matrix focused environment with emphasis on useless meetings, wasted time on redundant training, and a company that will trip over common sense to get to compliance then this is the place for you. Otherwise I would recommend that you go next door and apply at Clear Call or somewhere else.

pros: Excellent use of internet technology
cons: There is a lack of advancement opportunities

pros: Great pay with Supportive and Collaborative staff.
cons: School closed and is no longer at this location.

review_title: Good Company until DCEH took over
job_title: Assistant Program Director in Savannah, GA
pros: Good and flexible work environment
cons: Not much room for improvement

pros: They will pay for you to go back to school whether it is to do your terminal degree or take a class and get a degree in anything else that they offer.
cons: The various departments don't always have great leadership even though the university management is very transparent and doing a stellar job.

pros: pay is the best thing about the company
cons: leadership is the worst thing about the company

pros: Great faculty and staff. Motivated students. Accredited Licensed programs!
cons: Not a very well known school

pros: Growth opportunities to career ladder.
cons: Lengthy remote option to work from home.

pros: South University online has a great training department and they help new Admisisons Representatives with getting their feet on the ground.  The coworkers were nice and pleasant and fun to work with.  The facility was very well taken care of and nice to work in.  There is constant training in your role.  The benefits are great, plenty of overtime.
cons: The students that the university is going after do not have a proven track record of success, so they are not bought into education or South University as much as they should be to be successful.  Since it is recruiting (a form of sales) the bottom line is are you getting students in classes.  Compared to other universities I have worked for and attended there is too much hand holding with the students.  The line where responsibilities between departments is very blurry.  The company counts on Admissions Representatives too much to do too many things and holds them responsible when students do not attend. Environment on the floor seemed very micromanaged.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: decent work/life balance. Decent pay.
cons: No 401k matching, admissions driven

pros:
- Starting salary of 40k for admissions reps/recruiters. 
- Positive training experience with incredible training supervisor. 
- Overtime is sometimes available if you need more pay.
cons:
- Managers have no respect for employees. 
- HR only applies to new employees. Seasoned vets do whatever they want and get away with it, from sexual harassment to being truly cruel, abusive, and degrading to employees. 
- Many people who work here have criminal records. 
- HIGH turnover 
- The only employees who have worked there for a significant period of time are there because they make 6 figure incomes. They get paid extremely high salaries because the job used to be commission-based before the federal government changed that, ruling it unethical. However, employees at that period were "grandfathered" in to their current salaries. 
- I can't say enough negative things about this place. I would not wish this place on anyone. 
- Employees must follow "compliance" guidelines but are encouraged to basically trick" students into going to school so that South can rob them of their Pell funds and federal loans. 
- The graduation rate is practically nonexistent. 
- Students rarely finish more than one class. The goal is to get them to finish the first week of their second class, then they are financially responsive for both classes. 
- Cost per credit is $402, and each class is 4 credits. Outrageous!

pros: Pay and Paid Time Off
cons: High Stress Environment and Limited Career Advancement

review_title: High turn over in admissions, and leadership
pros: Nice location and facilities for students
cons: Management caused alot of discord amongst employees. Layoffs were inevitable- 2018.

pros: Great School learned a lot very helpful staff
cons: none none none none none

review_title: not looking out for best interests of students or employees.
pros: the ability to teach students
cons: administration does not listen to employees

pros: Consistent and easy course set-up
cons: Delays in promotions, low pay per course

pros: Your coworkers feel your pain.
cons: Forced to sell overpriced schooling to people who cannot afford it.  As in, nearly 70k for a bachelor's degree with no specialization.  And South cannot be bothered to pay for "good" leads, so we wound up calling people who were fresh out of prison (good on them for paying their debts and looking to better themselves, but frankly I never found one who could afford 70k after 17 years in prison).  Then there was the meeting we had with the new management after the institution was sold to Dream Center, who told us essentially, "We know it's way overpriced and what's that?  You've informed us that nobody knows who the heck we are?  Well, do better."  Turnover is insane, they will lie to you about the job until they have you in there (I was told THREE TIMES this is not a sales job, there is no quota, no worries, you're just talking to potential students."  My first three months there I had no manager, then I had one who had no business being there.  And then it was my fault I wasn't making quota.

pros: The co workers are the only positive
cons: Everyday is awful. Management smoothers you and threatens your job daily

job_title: Tutor in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: There are no pros at this campus.
cons: There are only cons at this camp

review_title: Worst place I have worked where upper management degrades others & the company is non-compliant with Title IV funding.
pros: Some good programs and nice building.  Enjoyed working with most of the local staff.  Pay was okay and benefits were good.
cons: Title IV regulations state that you can no longer monetarily incentivize admissions staff in recruitment for number of starts.  However, the company constantly threatened jobs if numbers were not hit.  At one point management wanted all of admissions put on a performance plan even though most of the staff worked very hard.  Very hostile work environment from the corporate leadership. I witnessed ridiculing, name calling, degredating emails, constant threats about my job and other's jobs, humiliation, micro-management, and ultimately firing admissions staff for not hitting their numbers.  This is a college that primarily cares about profit and secondarily about education.

pros:
- Starting Pay 
- Education benefits
- PTO / Flex time
cons:
- Pay freeze
(No raises given)
- Limited benefits 
(No 401k match)
- Far out location 

Simply put this company is one big discord! They preach about having quality conversations, and even created a service model based on a customer service experience for potential applicants. Yet, there is no understanding given by management if one doesn’t hit their (numbers) plan. What a total joke or catch 22 type situation!! 

Also, the reviews about HR & Mgt being attached at the hip is true! As I got fired for “unprofessionalism” after being scorned and yelled at by my direct manager. When I requested to be RESPECTED I was then threatened with HR. The story flipped flopped & they found the righteous guilty & vise versa.

review_title: Private not for profit university stabilizing and improving under independent management
job_title: Program Director in Round Rock, TX
pros: Enjoy close interactions teaching my students on campus with small class sizes. I know my students very well and they know I am available to meet with them and assist them toward successful program completion and graduation. Enjoy interacting and working with PD colleagues and upper management in online meetings working together on administrative issues and ongoing projects.
cons: Student tuition getting better but still higher than many competing state universities in local area of Central Texas and multiple online programs competing for same student population.  Wearing lots of different hats difficult to get all required administration tasks completed along with a lot of ongoing weekly courses preparation and planning for recruiting and hiring experienced Adjunct faculty every Quarter, very difficult to find and slow hiring process, due to no additional Full-time faculty positions in my department.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Novi, MI
pros: South University offers great benefits and competitive pay.  The schedule was not too bad, unless it was a start week.  The schedule was not depicted properly though in the interview.  Very professional atmosphere.
cons: Upper management did very little research on the market before putting a school there, then punished admissions when they weren't hitting their numbers.  Corporate acknowledged the struggles in the market and revisited marketing plans many times. They seem to be looking for scape coats in their ADA position rather than taking responsibility themselves, and fixing the mistakes.  Instead of giving employees necessary to succeed, they take those who aren't performing as well and just do whatever it takes to faze them out rather than giving them a fair chance to improve.

pros: Nice campus with ample space for parking.  Students can take classes online and on campus.  Faculty is great and are willing to help students.
cons: Campus lacks good leadership and positive work culture.  High turnover and lack of support and appreciate towards employees.   South University needs a facelift and to be brought into the 21st century.   CEO is out of touch with campuses and has an old style of leadership that has been doesn't generate a good work environment.   Lots of turnover throughout organization-nationally.  Communication is extremely poor amongst Administration to faculty and staff.

review_title: It was definitely time to leave, but I learned a lot.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Tampa, FL
pros:
-Admissions team was great until we all started leaving (Our team were almost all there for about 3.5-9 years up until this Fall)
-My own office
-Didn't really have to clock in/out, honor system 
-Great pay and benefits
-Work independently for the most part
-Great learning experience
cons:
-Unrealistic goals (~30 students per start/Quarter with mid-starts of about 10 in between)
-Other departments are lazy and rude to coworkers and students (Mainly financial aid and registrar)
-Job doesn't feel secure (but rarely seen anyone fired)
-High pressure sales that makes you feel like your crap
-3 Saturday's per month (on top of mon-fri)
-Black out dates pretty much 2-3 weeks every month
-Most likely will work on a holiday or that Saturday if Monday off

pros: Staff, pay rate is fair for the field, Strip District location, health benefits, parking raffle
cons:
Management, at every level. Undereducated people in high ranking positions at a University? No wonder education is the last focus. 
Unrealistic goals, questionable admissions policies, poor treatment of staff, moral conflict, loss of 401k... I think we get the picture.

review_title: Good experience, need more of an opportunity to move to different positions
pros: The pay is fair and the schedule is great.  Opportunity for advancement.  Overtime is available and optional.  Big company that has good benefits.
cons: Stressful atmosphere with quotas for new students.  They do not call it quotas but rather your "plan".  If you do not hit your plan then you are written up.  Do it enough and you are let go.

pros: EDMC pays generous salaries and provides decent benefits to the employees. New hire training is comprehensive and thorough. The company believes in promoting from within when management opportunities are available.
cons: There is little respect afforded to employees on an individual level. Performance is viewed quantitatively rather than qualitatively. Employee feedback is largely ignored and upper management often enacts new requirements and work processes without fully understanding the challenges the customer facing employees experience on a day to day basis.

pros: Good benefits and pay, there are opportunities to work overtime frequently and a good number of paid holidays during the year. Managers are willing to help as long as you ask for it.
cons: Call center environment, there is a lot of emphasis on 300+ dials a day or 4 hr+ talk time. Most of your calls are outbound which 95% don't answer or hang up on you, with the occasional inbound. This can make the day drag on. There is also a heavy focus on sales so you have to be comfortable "selling" the school  to potential students, even if you might feel they are not in it for the right reasons or it is not a great fit.

pros:
Okay pay for dialing all day. 
Nice coworkers.
cons:
*Extreme micromanage
*Unprofessional staff and management (I have never heard so many expletives used by management or co-workers).
*With possible sale to DCF that is pending you do not know if you will have a job by summer 2017.
*Extreme pressure by management to hit admissions numbers, when 95% are not hitting their goals
*Constant fear of getting a compliance violation due to management not communicating new regulations.
*Selling education to perspective students that are not qualified or interested in school or looking to get a stipend 
*Leads that are poor quality
*Overpriced degree programs
*I would add more, but I would need to write a book
Intimidation by leadership regarding ones ability and job security.

pros: Lots of pto events constantly
cons: First off the pay scale is completely out of whack no one gets hired at the same rate it doesn't matter if you all have the same qualifications. And those who have been there are still waiting on a long ago promised raise. But mostly there is zero consistency and you can get fired at any time for no reason or because the wrong person is judging how well you are implementing abusive recruiting tactics. Students are pushed through a process that is not beneficial to them at all. And if you have an ounce of integrity (as they preach to be key) you won't last

review_title: Not a Bad Place to Work
job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: The pay is not too bad. When I worked there, great manager who took me under her wing and really worked hard to see me succeed. They had a very good training program when was there. Two weeks of in-class type training and a week of on the floor training before being put on the team.
cons: Very high turn-over rate. There was a lot of instability with it's parent company EDMC. But as I was leaving, they were in the process of being bought out by a non-profit organization.

review_title: Great Team, Bad Leadership, Poor handling of training opportunities.
pros: I worked with a team of admissions reps, academic counselors, and finance counselors that were second to none.
cons: I had management that could not provide me with answers forcing me to rely on myself and peers. I was placed on leave and let go for something that was more of a training error or lack of training. Instead of counseled and worked with, another person on my team got into a similar bind and was allowed to stay with the company based on the tenure with the company.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Learned about industry standards such as regulatory compliance in the admissions realm.
cons: Almost everything. Company uses terrible recruiting tactics even after the whistle-blower lawsuit. Does not care about students at all. Will drag any student through the enrollment process whether it would benefit them or not. Tries to put them in programs that will get them nowhere and probably won't even have enough financial aid to cover the entire degree program. Students have no support after their first class- academic counselors have 400-500 students if not more to keep track of. Upper management will scream at your admissions manager right in front of you. Turnover of management and admissions is very high.

review_title: I Learned a lot about myself and leading/managing
pros: Working with great people. Everybody is educated to some extent and typically have outgoing, likeable personalities. Good pay with benefits. Free education.
cons: Little to no development from above. Leadership gives expectations (often times unrealistic) without aiding or providing guidance on how to meet/ exceed them. Unbalanced new student opportunity flow. There is potential though.

pros: Awesome campus president and campus administration. Small class sizes. Diverse student population. Great colleagues. Clean work environment. Secure. Wonderful staff. Good student support.
cons: Short quarters so hard to fit content for certain classes in the the 10 week period. Very low basis of admission (requirements) so some students really struggle with adapting to the college environment. This can make it a challenge to make instruction cater effectively to everyone if students of very low ability and students of very high ability in the same context.

pros: Overall atmosphere is based on hands off management and reward for a job well done. It is hard work and it can obviously be stressful at times but I know that compared to many places we have a lot of great benefits. It is rewarding work and the school itself is reputable so I can feel good about promoting to students. We have meetings and lunch and learn sessions to keep up on what is going on with the company and departments.
cons: Sometimes there is confusion when it comes to policies and it can take a bit of searching to get the right answer.

review_title: South University combines high ethical values and acute attention to detail in all of its day-to-day operations.
pros: The staff and faculty of South University care about one thing: getting students through their educational experiences in order to receive the career that they have always wanted. In most cases, the students receive individualized attention as often as needed.
cons: The only con--which can be perceived as a strength--is that the workload never lightens.there is always something that can/should be done during working hours.

pros: Hours are good, OT is compensated, Holidays, No take home work, People are sweet (majority)
cons:
1. The company brags about the benefits but does not offer a retirement match, and the healthcare isn't exactly on par with other companies. 
2. The company does not communicate things that can get you fired, I wonder why
3. AReps apparently last 0-6 months on average, fun fact 
4. Management never has an adequate explanation as to why certain people (even with less numbers than you) is in a higher tier 
5. A couple Admissions Managers are not good managers at all and their numbers show it, so hopefully you don't get that team 
6. Your motivation can't be helping people, cause you really aren't. You are screwing them out their money for a degree from a college that has an accreditation warning, owned by a company who over sees schools that just got shut down. For profit education is a joke to our country. 

Summary: you are signing up for a VERY regulated SALES job with CUSTOMER SERVICE type pay...no pay incentive for doing well or working hard... and moving up, forget that joke.. oh and look up the school's accreditation and reviews then try to sell economically vulnerable students a $60,000 degree from inquiries they don't even know that they made.. and let me know how that goes! If you kill it, congratulations, you get a nice high five, and don't get fired. 
Also, don't buy into their BS when they say that they used to be so good at what you do! TRUST ME, Higher Education and For Profits were not as watched as they are now. What you do is harder, and you don't get paid at all for it.

review_title: okay job for what it is.
pros: It is a relaxed atmosphere at time to a certain extent. The training was good,  enjoyed the people I worked with immensely. Good pay and Good benefits.
cons:
Honestly you have unrealistic expectations as to what it is you are supposed to do as an admissions representative. Often times depending on what team you are on greatly influences how you perform. If you are on a team without the leads that another team has you are held to the same standard as them which makes it very hard. The atmosphere of the job could be very tense at times do to the industry and falling stock price.

 You are almost expected to get blood out of a stone at times do the variables that are our of your control. Management does not care about this and believes that this is your job to fix this. Management and others listen to EVERY call and you can be written up or even let go if you slip up your wordage once. I understand this practice due to the nature of the business but saw many people just make a simple mistake get in trouble of something they had no idea about. 

I never felt secure with my job there as every week someone quit or was let go. I never saw a single person finish their two weeks there in the year I was there. Upper management comes across as very callous and paranoid even yelling at people for wearing "competitors' clothing on school spirit days wear they were encouraged to celebrate their alma maters. 

Another weird thing is that the company doesn't "fire" people very often but gives them a month long severance so that they will willingly quit so it shows they didn't fire them. 

The job is just a job but don't expect to make a career out of it.

review_title: Great people to work with but management needs to work on incorporating business goals into education.
job_title: Full-time Faculty, Health Sciences in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: The faculty at the South University campus in West Palm Beach were welcoming and always willing to help out. They were really there to help the students succeed.
cons: Many decisions about curriculum and scheduling were made with out input from faculty who would be most directly affected. These decisions were often made in Savannah with little consideration for different student populations at other campuses.

pros: Friendly co-workers, nice facility & decent benefits
cons: Find the total story by researching CNN Money article "For-profit college must give $103 million back to students"  November 16, 2015.  This will explain why you can be fired for 103 million reasons.  One misstep, and you are gone.  Daily threats come in the form of continual "shopping" by agencies; hoping to catch you saying one wrong word.  This place is hanging by a thread.  Look elsewhere for a job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Richmond Hill, GA
pros: Good salary and benefits are ok
cons: If you are a person who does not like a highly controlled atmosphere, this place is not for you. People go in their offices and shut their doors, spending hours alone in their office, sometimes in meetings via phone/computer. If you like face to face interaction, this is not for you. Vacation and sick time come from the same pool, so if you get sick, forget your vacation for the year......only 16 days total for the year.

pros: SU is a very well organized school with high student satisfaction ratings. Relationships among staff and between staff and students are remarkable, the school provides excellent benefits. It is by far one of the best companies I worked for.
cons: It is hard to advance from an adjunct to a full time instructor position. Does not provide discounted or free graduate education for employees.

pros: The work is not hard but it is repetitive. I find that I do the same thing every day with very little change. This makes for very little stress.
cons: As a creative person dining the same thing every day  is very painful. If you don't like a call center environment then stay away from this environment.

pros: Amazing team atmosphere. Great pay. My manager aways was coaching me and developing me.
cons: The position is for education, but really this is a sales position. If you can handle sales you can handle this job.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: At first the money based upon the number of students you started. That is until the US Dept. of Education intervened and stated that the corporate practice was illegal.
cons: Sweatshop. Bad moral where employees' jobs were constantly threatened. No help from supervisors or if there was help it was from someone who didn't do the job on a daily basis. Huge egos that were destructive towards the team environment. Many questionable sales tactics that might have seemed to steer ignorant candidates towards something they were not prepared for. By far, the worst place I ever worked. Unless you are hard up for a job, I would not recommend it. The aforementioned are my opinions.

pros: Your coworkers are enjoyable to work with.
cons: They make empty promises, don't care about their employees and will cut you loose despite your hardwork.  They are very quick to reprimand you however won't take the time to look into the root of the problem or responsibility for lack of training and informaiton provided. They ask employees to do one thing then management does a different thing.  They don't invest in their employees and would rather invest in new hire training classes to replace people than build up the employees they have.

review_title: Ok place to work, depending on your tolerance (online division)
pros: Good pay for Admissions, a lot of work to do for other positions (academics finance), raises finally being implemented this year
cons: lack of ability to move up, everyone that gets promoted is part of a inside click most people are not promoted based on skill, concerns and ideas from employees are not taken into consideration, pay is poor. something changes almost every week. Tools for you to be able to do your job successfully are not there.

review_title: I teach mathematics courses as assigned on an adjunct basis.
pros:
The academic freedom is beyond reproach. The administrative duties are light as compared to many other educational institutions. The MyMathLab and MyStatLab programs are easy to use and make preparing class materials, homework and tests a relatively easy requirement. 
The administration is firm but helpful and approachable.
cons: The biggest challenge is the large number of students in class. On the other hand, this is a good thing because it shows that the school is growing.

pros: flexible schedule, work from home on the hours convenient to you, well set online environment and working guidelines, direct management is nice.
cons: relative instability, you are not sure you'll get classes next time since it seems the class assignment is out of the hands of the respective department and is done by scheduling

pros: Not bad work schedule 8-5 and no weekends unless you want. Some co-workers are nice and you can actually trust and rely on
cons: It's a numbers company and if you have a conscience and talk about how you don't like things, get ready for things to get sticky. They don't like people who have their own ideas/opinions. People play dirty.

job_title: Student Finance Specialist, Financial Aid Officer in Savannah, GA
pros: Overall great professional atmosphere, everyone works together to help students achieve their goals. Very satisfying job and the benefits aren't too bad. I'd definitely recommend it to a friend.
cons: Not much room for advancement. The growth opportunities are pretty narrow. Pay compensation isnt the greatest, they pay the national average but expect us to do way more than what the position requires. There new procedure rollouts almost every other month, which makes it quite difficult to stay consistent.

pros: Some good caring people, if my supervisor was not in they would stop by and we could get some team work done.
cons: My supervisor was a micro manager that was in over her head and would lie, scream and talk to people in a hostile manner but she catered to the president.  I heard her lie to students, and other faculty, staff.  She never said one positive word about anyone the whole time I was there.

review_title: Could be a great place to work if changes are made
pros: salary, tuition reimbursement program, overall great co-workers
cons: Lack of leadership, lack of communication across departments, high pressure, no room to grow, extremely outdated technology, no culture

pros: You actually get to talk to great people every day and be a part of their hopes and dreams. Some of the employees and former-employees have been really wonderful.
cons: There is really no functional business model except bringing in more students however you can. Those admissions members who are better at this get away with anything they want. There are current employees who aren't in management positions but have had experience and have ideas on how to better student retention, build employee atmosphere, and actually lead and inspire  but management could care less. They get some lip service paid, but nothing comes of it. It is a field that is both Academic and Admission-based, which is actually sales, but focus is mainly on sales. The academic team is severely overworked, short-staffed, and underpaid. Management has no idea what the academic team actually does, because they were promoted from admissions. And, they show no sign of actually want to learn. There is no leadership-team interaction, only mandates. In fact, the only time one really hears from a manager is when you do not perform, or when there is a compliance issue that needs to be fulfilled. There is a lot of talk about South University being a 'student-centered' institution, but their notion of student-centered is overpromising and creating expectations in order to admit a warm body to the university. The rest is an academic counselor or manager attempting to downplay expectations, telling them what's really going to happen, and handling escalated calls. There is really nothing academic about it. Just a lot of listening, patronizing, and putting out fires.

review_title: Not a good work environment (South University Online division, Pittsburgh)
pros: Good pay, some nice people, but other than that, I have nothing positive to say about working for South University.
cons: It's a constant environment of fear. From the moment you are hired, everyone is telling you to watch your back or you'll be fired. It is a sales environment at the end of the day, and it's made completely obvious that enrolling students and getting them to start class is put above all else, no matter how it affects the student. Middle management tries to act like you're doing something good, but both employees and students are treated like commodities rather than people. Upper management refuses to acknowledge that the school just isn't that great and looks to blame the lower men on the totem pole for not recruiting enough rather than make changes that would actually make the school appealing to students (the online division has a 2% graduation rate). If you express any discomfort at all, you will be encouraged to quit. Also, in the six months I was there, I had three managers as well as a long period in time with no manager. There's no consistency and no regard for employees, except for friends of management who can get away with anything. While I was there, a long time worker for the company and friend of a high ranking employee showed up to work probably on drugs and was heard saying he wanted to shoot and stab people (to be fair, this is through third hand information; I didn't hear it directly, but I know the man in question and there is no doubt in my mind this is true). He was simply sent home for half a day and allowed to come back the next day like nothing was wrong. Also, I'm a young woman (20s), and literally every male employee over 40 I came into contact with while working here was just creepy and wouldn't stop hitting on me. One even messaged me on LinkedIn to give me his phone number! Typical things you have to deal with as a woman, I guess, but really uncomfortable.

pros: Decent starting pay and they pay OT
cons: The office politics here are the worst I have EVER seen!  ALL of upper management including the Director and HR are good buddies so don't fool yourself into thinking you will get to move up.  They froze pay raises 3 months after I started and this was after giving me a written offer letter with a guaranteed pay raise after one year.  The team I was on had the worst manager I've ever encountered in my entire life.  He literally does nothing all day long except walk around and gossip with people.  If you need help with something good luck!  But if you don't hit your numbers he will be in your face screaming at you until he is blue in the face because that's how he keeps his job!  But don't think for a second you can talk to HR about it!  My co-worker and I complained to HR about him and literally begged for help with training and things to help us become better at our jobs. The HR lady wrote down both of our names.  Appoximately 6 weeks later this co-worker and I were BOTH fired on the exact same day for BS made-up nonsense!  I'm not bitter, I am much better off.  But be warned, you CANNOT talk to HR in confidence here!

pros:
Good Salary
Good Benefits
Nice Campus 
Central location
Attached to the Art Institute-love the smell of the cooking from there.
cons:
Micromanaging from Administration-taking away a coffee stand that was a pleasant place to get a healthy snack. Campus president didn't like the table, so he moved the service. No input from students, employees or guests.
I had to listen to calls made to students requesting money. Some of the calls were painful to hear, harassing students for "any payment they could make."  Often students would be threatened with no transcripts or no grades. Very mean spirited.
Low morale in the workforce that does feel their input is important (see the coffee stand as above). Rule made no drinks or food at employee desk, yet faculty lounge has no place to wash hands and campus president always has something to drink on his desk.
There is no planned orientation for new faculty. Often teachers are brought onboard that have never taught before and become very stressed out since they do not know about any of the computer systems, school policies, etc. Instructors are teaching subjects without any experience in the subject matter.
Students are given assurances upon matriculation that often change. Students were "promised" their classes will be available online, and then the school "phases it out" to save money. Changing the instruction method in the middle of the program increases stress on students.The student knows that their South University credits will not transfer to another school, so they don't have many options.

review_title: Changes within the company are constant. Disorganized & heavy work load causes stressful feelings.
pros: Great people, decent PTO, nice location if you're centrally located in the Chandler area. Good work hours & Overtime is usually available.
cons: Company struggles, unsure of the lifespan of company and business is enduring major changes per Dept of Ed. Turn over is high & jobs seem unstable & irreplaceable.

pros: Great place to work and meet people.  Everyone is so nice and helpful. Able to pursue your education.
cons: I worked the shift of 12 - 8 and Saturday's as well.  Long week, but well worth it.  Wonderful place to work.

pros: There are no Pros for this degree mill.
cons:
Constant faculty and leadership turnover.
Too many campuses, each trying to outdo the other. 
Too many adjunct faculty and not enough full-time faculty who are vested in students.
Although South University touts they are private not-for profit; the same people from Dream Center and EDMC  still work at South including the Chancellor

pros: Pay is good, benefits are good, great coworkers
cons: No support for promoting withing. Dangling of carrot in front of you to keep performing. NO PERSON OF COLOR in any upper management level for the entire organization

review_title: A very enlightening experience in proprietary education.
pros: This campus has a varied non-traditional student body which is the demograhic I most enjoy working with.
cons: Oppurtunities for upward mobility and the process for getting there are not well identified.

pros: Salary is competitive, benefits are good
cons: The administration is micromanaging. The campus president and dean of the college allow students to complain about faculty to them, without redirecting the student back to the faculty first. The administration makes "new rules" or "special circumstances" for students so faculty are literally powerless to conduct classes fairly and achieve desired outcomes.

pros: A dedicated higher institute of learning, where the Dean and the faculty knows everyone by name, literally. Achievement and success are the primary goals at South University,  not only for students but for staff.
cons: Currently there is not a Doctorate program for Clinical Mental Health Counseling.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Savannah, GA
pros: Helping the students, receiving tuitition assistance for myself. My co-workers are all educated interesting individuals that I enjoy talking to.
cons: Pressure, high stress, mulitiple departments looking over your shoulder.

pros: Virtual environment was great and convenient when it comes to addressing student concerns and facilitating courses. In addition, it was a very relaxed, yet professional environment.
cons: It appears that views of non-management were not taken seriously. Also, it was very difficult to encourage student success when my concerns were not discussed specifically.

pros: strong curriculum and awesome faculty. Enjoy working for my Dean. The new campus president is very approachable and likes to engage with faculty and students. Looking forward to next few years here.
cons: Corporate changes are creating confusion

review_title: Good training first few weeks. It's hell after that. Find a real school to work for.
pros: Pay and benefits was okay. With the expectations they had if us, we deserved more. Writing this last sentence to meet the 20 word requirement. *rolls eyes*
cons: No support, academic probation, low retention, cliquey managers, too much pressure and no support. Writing this last sentence to meet the 20 word requirement. *rolls eyes*

review_title: Very thorough training and positive environment.
pros: Love the managers, work environment, cafeteria on site, training, free education, chances at advancing to next level. Lots of opportunities. Awesome hours- off by 3 or 4pm!
cons: Cubicle environment and is like telemarketing. Managers closely listen to conversations.

pros: Helping students obtain education.  Working with like minded, educated coworkers.
cons: Leaders have unrealistic expectations.  It is a sales gig, plain and simple no matter how else they try to frame the organization.

job_title: Tutor and IT Problem Solver in Kenosha, WI
pros: For the most part, we were given the tools we needed to do our jobs.
cons: The pay was low across the board and this caused hostile work environment.

pros:
-good pay
-meet good people
-good first job for professional experience
cons:

-the don't tell you what the job really is until your in it
-more sales than higher education
-have to meet numbers even though you don't make commission

-lay offs happen all the time

review_title: South was great but Dream Center Education ruined everything
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Novi, MI
pros: Excellent pay, great campus leadership, wonderful teammates, rewarding job
cons: higher up leaders were sneaky and had their own agenda, hours did not offer much of a work/life balance

pros: The paycheck hit my account has scheduled.
cons: It wouldn’t have been so bad dealing with the absolute nightmare that is the student population if coworkers and management would have been somewhat decent. I dealt with the most TERRIBLE students and had ZERO support from management. Speaking of management: I have never met a more dishonest, incompetents, and self-serving group of people in my entire life.

review_title: A geat experience with hands-on instructors
job_title: Instructor, Criminal Justice in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: The University allows its instructors to teach based on their personal life experiences
cons: In my six years as an adjunct, I cannot find anything negative about this university

pros: Decent pay for adjuncts. Many really nice people to work with.

job_title: Career Services Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Loved the people I worked with, and I loved helping the students
cons: lots of red tape, couldn't get anything done without having it approved from multiple people

pros:
Nice campus
Supportive Management
Decent adjunct pay
cons: Professional Development not differentiated to meet individual needs

review_title: Good job, to many other responsibilities not in job description.
pros: Good job, good people to work with every day. Great benefits, parking.......
cons: Responsibilities grow but pay and recognition do not. Management doesn't look at the talent they have working for them.

job_title: Assistant Program Director in Savanna Place, GA
pros: Online - peers are great to work with.
cons: Administration can be difficult.  Faculty suggestions aren't always accepted.

pros: There is always support when you need it. Small classes.

review_title: Sinking Ship with No Interest in Helping
pros: set hours, decent insurance. Free education or pay taxes on masters degree!
cons: Horrible politics, arrogant management that does not understand what it is like to be on the phones all day. Refusal to train even when asking for help repeatedly. Lots of change and very confusing, high demand jobs. Froze pay raises.

pros: I enjoy working and helping students succeed.
cons: We need more full time and adjunct instructors.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Bloomington, IL
pros: Customer service, helping others create a better future, flexible hours, and team culture
cons: Not all of the programs were supported by management, grew too much too fast, poor communication, lack of leadership

pros: Convenience of working online is nice.
cons: Where to begin. Disorganized, one admin after another to avoid bankruptcy. Inferior educational services for students, staff that are ill informed and incompetent. In short, a sinking ship that should be avoided. It's sinking for a reason folks, and that reason is it is inferior.

pros: I liked my position because I had freedom to create and implement lessons as I saw fit.
cons: Wish the school was larger. Would have loved the opportunity to teach more classes.

pros: Great coworkers at the local level. Flexible hours in the faculty positions.
cons: Many workers are taken advantage of by being assigned additional roles in which they are not compensated fairly or at all.

review_title: Great first job right out of college
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Savannah, GA
